description:
Bosea vestrisii is a species of flowering plant belonging to the family Amaranthaceae. It is a perennial herb native to the Canary Islands, located off the northwestern coast of Africa.

The plant is characterized by its small, green flowers arranged in clusters or spikes. The leaves are simple, oblong to lanceolate in shape, and typically have a greyish-green color. Bosea vestrisii is known to grow in rocky, dry habitats, often found on coastal cliffs or in areas with well-drained, sandy or rocky soils.

Taxonomically, Bosea vestrisii is classified within the genus Bosea, which includes several species of perennial herbs or subshrubs found primarily in the Mediterranean region and Macaronesian islands. The specific epithet "vestrisii" refers to the plant's association with the Canary Islands, where it is endemic.

As a member of the Amaranthaceae family, Bosea vestrisii shares certain morphological and ecological characteristics with other plants in this family, such as their adaptation to arid and semi-arid environments.
